div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: A Fight for the Nation's Box Seat
div.p: The "Times" sums up the policy of the Labour Party by admitting it is a fight "for the box seat"

Mr. Walter Sichel, writing in the "Times" says that the real issue is "the extinction of the middle class and the gradual inducement of conditions under which the plutocrat and the pauper can alone survive". "This is", thinks the "Times", "putting it too picturesquely, yet it is true that the middle class has now to endure an assault upon its political predominance such as it delivered nearly a century ago upon the political supremacy of the upper class. It won a great victory with the first Reform Bill, and for a long time went on consolidating its power. But it cannot be said to have used its power much better than its precessors, and now it is being called to account

"It evolved and acted upon an inhuman and unsocial system of political economy, under which it called into being an immense industrial population, which it exploited in the name of supply and demand, and allowed to live without education, without physical comfort, without any right but that of selling its labour for what it could get. That population found the leadership which the captains of industry denied it, created an organization for itself obtained from the dissensions of its masters a continually increasing share of political power and very substational ameliorations of its lot Now it is trying a fall with its masters exactly as they did with the landed and aristocratic intrest. It is no longer trying for more comfort at the back of the coach, but is seeking possession of the box-seat; and the class it is trying to oust regards its efforts with distraction, with alarm, with acute apprehension, but without any very intelligent conception of the real state of affairs of the way to make the best of it.

"That way is not to be found in despairing efforts to cling to the old order of things. Poeple complain of the apathy of the middle classes, but that apathy is mere perplexity, arising from lack of reasoned views about the consitution of a properly constructed and managed society. Though it is late in the day, it would be well to begin by frank recognition of the change that is upon us, and to go on with intelliegnt and disinterested efforts to lightenly of ignorantly, they will fight their battle for the supremacy which they wanr ro enjoy in the direction of the State, and the object to all men of good will ought to be to minimize as much as possible the mistakes that are sure to be made during the conflict"

"The Socialist bugbear is not the key of the situtation. The poeple of this country are far too intensely individualistic to be permanently deceived by Socialist theories. But in a fight all allies are welcome, and up to a certain point Socialism will doubtless be used to promote the general aim. In sheer ignorance the working men may be induced to destroy as belonging to others things that, if they knew better, they would gladly keep for themselves. The best hope for the future lies, not in trying to put life into outwordn political dogmas and traditions, but in endeavoring to show the new owners of political power how much there is in the institutions of their country which it is their intrest to conserve for the benefit of themselves and their children. If this people perish, it will be for the lack of knowlegde, not for want of native recitude and common sense"

div.head: An Islamic Problem.
div.p: In another portion of to day's issne we pu blish some extracts from a very important arti cle by Professor Margolioath, which deals with a problem of vital importance for the regener ation of Egypt. The acknowledgment on the part of Moslems that their religion has proved inferior to others in the meotal and moral equipment of its followers, is the first step towards the reform of Islam. It is no longer denied that for knowledge, for comfort, and for personal satety Moslems go to cduntries of which the governing power is Christian, and emigrate from such as are under Moslem domination, and the question why this shonld be suggests itself to many minds.

div.p: In our issue of Thorsday last we announced that the report which had gained currency in Paris of the combine of the new line to Egypt with the Hamburg American Line was incor- rect, and that arrangements have been made with the Hamburg Line which are expected to prove eminently satisfactory from the point of view of both companies and the travelling public. ‘The Egyptian Mail Steamship Company have incorporated the Hamburg American ser vice in their improved service, and the German hoats will no longer run in the Mediterranean, Mr. Otte Sterzing, Agenc of the North German Lloyd at Cairo, writes to-day that this does not refer to his Company's steamers aa the Norddeutscher Lloyd alone is running in the Mediterranean six different passengers lines, not counting the freight lines, viz Marseilles Naples- Alexandria, Marseilles or Genon Naples lireas-Constantinople te the ports of the Black Sea, Genoa-Naples-Port Said to Aanstrafie, Gibraltar-Algiers-Genoa Naples-Port Said to Eastera Asia, Genoa-Naple-Gibraltar to New York, Alexandria Smyrna-Constantinople (Cons tantza with the Roumanian steamers

div.head: ALEXANDRIA-RAMLEH TRAMWAY.
div.p: TRIAL OF NEW CAR

Yesterday afternoon by invitation of the Alexandria and Ramleh Tramway Company, Limited, we made, in company with several others, the trial trip to the Palais on the first new mixed tramcar to be placed on the Alex- andria-Ramleh line’ The ran was an eutire success and we are convinced that the pablic will experience the same satisfaction with the new cars as was expressed hy those who made the journey yesterday

The cars in question are adapted for use with absolute comfort both in summer and winter. In winter they are closed in, and in summer they will be opened by the removal ot the windows and panels on either side of the car. In winter entrance to the car is made at either end and there is a central passage between the transversely placed seats, whereas in summer this passage will afford further seating accommodation and entrance to the ear will he made from either side. Each car is divided equally for the accommodation of first and second class passengers, the only difference between the two being the provision of the comfortable “Kattan” seating for the former class. The cars, indeed, are constructed with every view to comtort and the decorative part of the work is thoroughly artistic, while both shaking and jerking have been reduced to a minimuin, no matter what the speed

The accommodation of a single-decked car of this type, such as we travelled in yesterday, is 46 when closed for the winter and 60 when opened for the suromer, the over-all length being 12.80 métres. Phe length of the car ased upto the present is 8 1/2 metres with an accommodation (single deck) of 20 in those with longitedinally placed seats and 40 in those with transversely placed seate. The doable decked car now in use is seated for 56 persons, whereas those of the new type can seat 92 when closed in and 116 when open.

A considerable advance has also been macie in speed. The cars at present on the line were able on trial to run at the rate of 45 kilometres an hour, while the car which we travelled on yesterday has ron at the rate of 60 kilometres per hour. Indeed, throughout our trip yesterday our car was anable to do justice to its constructors as regards speed as it was held in check by the car which left the station before it. The points and carves were negotiated without noticeable jerking or swerving, aod, as we have already mentioned, the shaking was remarkably slight at every spec, except ‘laring the passage over the short length of grooved lines. Another point of advantage, which must not be overlooked, is the control which the experienced wattman bas over his car. these cars going at their maximam speed can be brought to a stop in a length of about 50 metres, thoagh such a short pall-up would, as may well be imagined, be by no means agreeable to the nnanticipating passenger
In conclusion let us wish the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company, Limited, “mabrouk” in their effort to satisfy the in creasing demands of the public

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN U.S.A
div.p: Secretary Wilson, of the Department of iculture at Washington, in an address de ivered on the 8rd inst., said -— . “The farmers of these localities (Louisiana and Mississipi) are beginning to compre. hend the situation which confronts them Demonstration work has been organised, and the t is teaching methods of grow ing cotton aud diversifying crops to more than a hundred thousand farmers throughout Texas, Louisiana and Mississipi, who are now work: ing along these lines During the past year it has been demonstrated that Egyptian cottons can be successfully grown on ovr soil. We have been importing millions of dollars worth of these cottons for the manufacture of certain kinds of goods. Various efforts have been made to grown Egyptian cotton here in past years, but none have succeeded. This year we have prodaced from three-qoarters of a bale to to a bale of bigh grade Egyptian cotton under irri gation conditions in the Southwest.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
div.p: THE ZIZINIA SPEECH.

The moderate section of the Egyptian Ne tionalist Party are very indignant at the tone of Mostapha Pasha Kamel's speech, whieh has been the object of a great deal of hostile critics” in the columns of the Moslem verns- tentative, the authorities might be inclined to make in the way of Egyptian self-government. It is thought that the tone of the speech will even have a deplorable effect on the handfull of Radicals in the House of Commona, whe have been of late inclined to consider the claims of the Nationalists. Such leading organs of Natioualist opinion as “Al Moayad,” “Al Minbar,” and “Al Guerida,” take the Pasha severely to task. The latter journal remarks “If the Pasha knows how to remain within bounds, the ignorant classes do not, and he ought to ex- plain such expressions as ‘the poliey of hatred,’ “especially as the Occupation is able to tarn the slightest movement to the prejudice of our patriotic rights.” The insulta, whieh the Pasha heaped on the Nationalista, who refuse to bow down to him as the one and only orthodox ex- ponent of Nationalism, are deeply resented by “Al Minbar,” which considers that Kamel's claims to the monopoly of patriotism are atter- ly inadmissible.

div.head: THE SCENE OF THE EARTHQUAKE.
div.p: Visitors to Calabria are nowadays so tew and far between that the news of the terrible havoc, which has just been wronght by the earthquake, will na,appeal to many. And yet Gerace, where the telegrams say that the cathedral has been utterly destroyed is in one of the loveliest, thoagh most neglected corners of Burope, and the beauty of the scenery of the bridle-road from Gerace over the Aspromonte by the Passo del Mercante tu Casalnooro leaves an indelible impression on every tra- veller's memory. Gerace is the see of a bishop and is on the upper slopes of the lofty moan- tains which extend from the great backbone of the Apennines into the sea. It was a place ot great strength in the middle ages, bat frequent earthquakes, particularly that of 1783, have re duced its citadel to ruins The cathedral, which has been ruined a few days ago, was originally a Gothic building and was overwhelmed in the catastrophe of 1783. lts buildings are pictaree- queand contain many marks of Saracenic influence. Gerace sprang trom the ruins of Locri Epizephyrii whose citizens are so cordial- ly praised in the 11th Olympic of Pindar. There is a beautiful aketeh of Gerace, by Mr. Lear The acthor of “Pyramids and Progress,” Mr. Ward, in bie werk on Greek coins, ssys “The glorious scenery of this part of southern Italy, its massiveness and its breadth, is stil) in full evidence, and the sites of the modern towns are remarkably pictaresque. The blue sky and sunshine, the bealthy, well-grown peasantry — whose women still retain their picturesque ancient costumes (unfortanately anly seen on Sundays and fete-days)—make it one of the richest grounds for the artist. If only some of our modern watercolour painters would spend their spring or avtumn holidays there, they might then show that Mr. Lear, the landscape painter of fifty years ago, only gave usasmall sample of its inexhaustible love lineas.”

It is impossible to locate the town of Ferruzanno, which is said to have been com pletely destroyed, as no such name is discover able in any map of Suuthern Italy. Possibly Pavazzina, between Bagnera end Scilla, may be meant
Sir Thomas Fowell Buxton, GC MG, the Rev. Harold Buxton, who arrived t this morning, are staying at the New Kheivial Hotel
Judge Bond, vice-President of the Native Court of Appeal is due back on the 15th proxo The rumours of his impending retirement are without foundation

We regret to announce the death of Mr Jules Mirguet, an Inspector in the Ministry of Public Instruction, which has occurred at the French hospital at Abbassieh after a long illness.

Mr. William Martin Hewat, civil engineer, of the Towns and State Buildings Department of the Ministry of Publio Works, is shortly retiring from the service of the Egyptian Go- vernment. He is now on his return to Egypt by a Mose liner and is due at Alexandria shortly.
Mr. and Mrs. T. H. Manley are due back at Alexandria on Monday from their honeymoon trip round Sootland.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our coorespondent, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion

div.head: LONDON OPINION
div.p: London,October 17th
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,—We have been much struck over here by the portentous accounts of the homecoming of Mastapha Pasha Kamel People are not slow to recognise thet the historical agitator has no more force than a spent balloon. Moreover, the method of sensational self- advertisement as though some crisis were near has become a weariness. His "two-words" might have been two thoosand forall the convic tion they carried with them. Two thousand would indeed have been far more in accord with a prolix and pretentious past. Excitable references to imaginary happening, much feverish declamation and high falutin rhetoric and flourishes are not called for. They are dangerous too in a measure, for the so-callled "campaign" has had a slight effect- fortunately only slight- in confusing people's minds. Luckily it is recognised here that the theatrical proceedings of a certain speechifier have really nothing to fo with the cause of Egypt and its welfare; these are in the hands of more sober- minded workers whose propaganda was of value during the summer that has just gone. The reprehensible attempt then to cloud the issue in the intrests of sundry personal ambitions, and the grinding of certain axes- and to create among the casual spectators an undeniable mistiness as to who really are the representatives of a quielty moving forward party- has failed as it deserved. At the same time it is as clear to the observer in London as to the on-looker in the East that the question of the advancement of Egypt should be entrusted finally to those who worked so zealously for the cause in London during the past year. The moderate programme of reforms which was put forward is one which can well recieve the whole-hearted support of the nation, and the more it is realised in Egypt that even the temporary recognition as spokesmen of this one or the pther, qui que ce soit, is nugatory, the better really for all concerned. Discredited agitators are still capable of mischief by bringing about the party splits. Having once tasted the pleasures accuring to the position they have been found significantly unfit - they are loth to relinquish one iota of the privileges thus improperly retained. But the steady advance towards a great ideal must not be hampered by such veniality. The heathen should be given no opportunity to blaspheme. The observer or the biased critic should not have any reason for their comment, "Oh, there are so many parties, so many leaders, they do not know what the wish". Nothing could be more unjust than such a rfemark. Unfortunately where there is an unfair comment to be made, only too often it finds egress. We must bear in mind this evidence of human weakness. It behoves thinking Egyptians to be as staunch to the atual leaders of theparty of reform and the national cohesion as to teh idea itslef. Let, there be no mistake as to this. Events are watched narrowly in London. Though there is a real readiness to salute the desire of prominent Egyptians to emphasise the integrity of their country- since who but the Egyptians themselves can prosper in such a task- there is also existing in certain quaters a disposition to cavil and to ump to the conclusion that because certian loud-talking demagogues have made their names familiar through the columns of the French press both in Paris and the East, that the country is divided, and that there is no great heart of Egypt, no unity of prupose, but only a number of futile cabals whose actions end in trifling and smoke. Now, this is not so. I make no excuse for devoting this letter to this one subject, for we here have had it dinned into our ears ad nasuseam that teh return of a certain airy political trifler was something in its way epoch-making. Poeple who knowvery little of a subject are porverbially easy to convince, but one may confidently assert that only a small section of the public both here and in Cairo has been influenced by the rapid outpouring of a self-stylef patriot. Still it is regrettable that even an infinitesimal section should be misled by a few shouts and a cheer or two from a chance crowd. In all centres of population a crowd will cheer at the slightest provocation, and generally with no clear idea as to the reason for the applause. One man rasies a shout, and the first passer-by stops and imiatates him. This is the Simian strain in the race. It must be recognised that the leaders of the movement, who spent a month here in the summer, have earned the support of theri fellow countrymen. It is not a pleasant little game, with personal notoriety as the first prize and as proxime accessit the right to be escorted to your carriage by a few score idlers. Consequently it is a real duty to give no countenance to every upstart who can issue a proclamation or utter a few platitudes in the public ear. Let it be remembered that all that is necessary for the movement has been said, that the seed is sown, and that the work is on the way, being carried on under the suspices of men who are not self-seeking, but who have been prodigal of time brains and money, in order to advance. In this connection it is not a question of the Irish party, not the Labour perty, nor any little clique, supporting the movement, which is independent of them all, though there is good service from many quaters. Englishmen who are strong for the Empire are also strong in apporval. I should like to conclude by pointing out that those who give whole-hearted support to these leaders of the movement, who have put in years of unacknowledged self-sacrificing duty will not discovery any lack of enthusiasm in the procescution of the great work, though it is pursued without any empty protestations and noisy fanfaronnades
I am, Sir, Truly yours, A London Radical
London, October 17th

Dear SIr- Thinking that your readers would be glad to have a more extended notice of the late Rev. Chauncey Murch D.D., whose sudden death took place recently on a dahabia at Assuah, I give you the following particualrs. Dr Murch was born in the State of Penn- sylvania USA. om January 1st 1856, and was graduated at Muskingham College, Ohio, i 1876. He came to Egypt a» « missionary in 1883 in connection with the American Mis sion, and was stationed for a time at each of the follwoing places, Benha, Tanta, and Luxor; his first and last appointments being Luxor, where he spent the longest part of his missionary life, and from which as a centre he made many visits on the Mission Nile boat to the towns and villages situated between Tahta and Assuan, which compromised the district of which he has superintendence. While stationed in Luxor he used some of his spare time in reading books on Egyptology and took a great intrest in antiquities, and learned to read hieroglyphics, and was an expert on deciding what was new and old among relics offered for sale. He was held in high esteem by men of all creeds, nationalities, and was noted for his readiness to render assistancee to anyone in need. Indeed I never met any man so ready to give of his time, of his talents, and of his strength for the benefit and even the enjoyment of others. He will be greatly missed, espically in the Thebaid where he was much beloved by by many. He leaves a wife and only one son to mourn his loss. Hundreds of telegrams or letters to, or personal calls upon, his bereaved wife testify to the esteem in which he was held.
Yours Truly, Knox
Cairo, October 25

div.head: Cairo to Helouan
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir- The word seems to be going round that the whilom prejudice to Helouan would have long time worn away, were the place acessible to the Caireue in any other manner than by the railway, which tends almost to make the place as remote as Alexandria is from Cairo, for the disparity of distance in the latter journey, is made up for by the discomfort in the former

The isolation of Helouan however may after all hold some advantages, for are not rents and freeholds cheaper there to-day than at any other place in Egypt? In fact if one looks round and nders these things, it is the one place left where prices so far have not been fabulously overdone. This is all the more remarkable too, when on reflects the advantages and attractions that Helouan has to offer, such as its mineral baths, sumptous hotels, and many pensions, its desert rides, golf links, race course, not to mentionits observatory from which many and wonderful things foretold, even to the extent of earthquakes at no less a distance than 8000 miles away, and all these vivid attarctions are denied to the general body of Cairenes, for the reason that the journey in getting there and back is so irksome and tedious

I have pointed out inyour columns that the land for a road is available. This one presumes to mean the Nile bank, and thta labour is there, free to the Government, through the medium of the 1,000 able-bodied male convicts denied erstwhile at Tourah prison. Then why not connect up this suburb, as other suburbs have been or are being connected up, by a well metalled road, which would last at least half a century if the same class of stone is still to be found in the Mukattams as was employed by the ancients in constructing the Pyramids -Yours etc
Cairene. Cairo, 24th October, 1907

div.head: EGYPTIAN LIBERAL PARTY
div.p: Monsieur le Directur de "l'Egyptian Gazette"
J'ai l'honneur d'attirer votre attention sur deux erreurs dans la traduction de ma depeche a Moustapha Kamel que vous avez bien voulu publier dans "l'Egyptian Gazette" du 24 courant

Dans la 4me ligne, vous employez les mots: "our vileness" voulan dire: "yuor vileness". Ainsi que dans la 21me ligne vous traduisez: "Que Dieu vous combatte" par "may God fight you and me." Le texts orginal est que Dieu le combatte (lui-meme) c.a.d, que les mota "and me" sont superflus.
Veuillez agreer, mon cher directeur, l'assurance de ma parfaite consideration
Mohamed Wahid
Helouan, le 25 Octobre
The Moss liner "Menes" arrives at Gibraltar yesterday morning bound for Alexandria

div.head: St. Mary's Mission, Cairo
div.p: RETIREMENT OF REV. N. ODEH

By the retirement of the Revd. N. Odeh, lastelt Rector of St. Mary's Mission, Kasr El Donbars, a long career of uninterupted Mission work in the East comes to a close a career full of intrest, anecdote, and success, but none the less traversed by many a hard trial and struggle which would have discouraged men not gifted with the knowledge, experience, and administrative spirt that were so helpful to the departing Rector. For we may safely say that few Anglicans- clerical or lay- are better aquainted with affairs of Church and State in the Orient, or more qualified to prounounce an opinion thereon, or could act with greater prudence in an emergency, than the Revd. Mr. Odeh.

Taking Holy Orders in 1879, he was sent to take charge of the Mission at Ramlah, (Lydda) in the Plain of Sharon, where he remained one year. Ordained a Preist by the late BishopBarely in Jerusalem, the Revd. Mr. Odeh, ministered for five years each at Christ Church, Nazareth and St. Paul's Jerusalem. From the Holy City he was transferred, seventeen years ago, by the present Anglican Bishop, to Cairo, to found a Chruch Mission. He opened Mission Schools first at Hamzawi, then in the Jewish quater, the Mousky, Abdin, Kasr-el-Nil, and, finally, twelve years ago, the present compound one acre in size, was aquirred near the residence of General Bullock, and a boys' and girls' school and mission house built by a mortgage was redeemed two years ago, when by the advice of the Revd. Mr. Odeh, the name of the Bishop in Jerusalem, and would therefore revert to the State on the Bishop's demise was converted into Wakf, or religious entail, the trustees being the Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem, wh has jurisdiction in Egypt, and the Secretary General of the S.P.G., and their successors for ever, according the Moslem law. St. Mary's Church, now in course of construction, is the last addition to the Mission buildings, and crowns the work which the Revd. Mr. Odeh has done. It is in the Byzantine style, of brick and stone throughout, and, without the gallery, will accommodate a congregation of five hundred, as against the hundred souls now seated in the chapel. When roofed, the Church, fronting Kasr El Ain Avenue, will be a great improvement to the surroundings from an architectual point of view, and its situation should ensure it a fashionable congregation. The money forthis Church, by the bye, was collected by Revd. Mr. Odeh by voluntary subscription and without any grant from the Bishops Fund in England. Considerable economies were effected in the work of construction, and the right of preemption, used, to prevent the sale of a strip of land on one side of the Church. The Mission property was valued last season, at from L.E 100 to 120,000, and having freed itself of debt, it is on a satisfactory financial basis. But this is not all that Revd. Mr. Odeh has done, in Cairo. As regards education religious and secular- in point of moral upfilt and progress, we have every cause to be pleased with the life work of Mr. Odeh not only in Syria, but in this Land of Nile as well. To-day, upwards of 150 boys and girls of all nationalities and creeds attent the primary and secondary classes of the Mission Schools, and many an Egyptian, in offical or civil employ, has pleasing reminiscennces to tell of the Christian principles which were expounded so sympathetically to him in the shade of the euclyptus of that oasis of calm and good will
The faculty as at present consituted, consists of four English masters, two assistants an Arabic and in French Professor, and two English lady teachers.

The Rev. Mr. Odeh was Principal of the Schools, and the Chaplain of the Mission, but these duties have developed respectively on the Rev. T. a. Braithwaite, D.D. Oxon, L.L.D Dublin, and Mr. F.J. Ney lately Headmaster of the English School, Niscosis, Cypress

More than this, Mr. Odeh has prepared a fir residence and propert for the Anglican Bishop of Egypt, whose nomination is immient. Towards the fund of L.E. 30,000 required for this purpose, the Jerusalem and East Mission Fund have collected L.E. 16,000, and the S.P.G and Colonial Bishoprie may each contribute L.E. 5,000 if the remaining L.E 10,000 is forthcoming

Mr. Odeh had many true friends during his sojourn in Cairo, and among them was Lord Cromer, who always sympathised with the work that the Mission was doing, and used hif good offices with the Egyptian Government to sell the land at Kasr-el-Doubara at half price. His leadership invariably attended the annual school-treats and expressed in very kind words, his appreciation of the effort of Mr. Odeh and his colleagues
Bishop Blyth, on his yearly circuit always stayed at St. Mary's Mission House, and ever showed the deepest sympathy with the Rev. Odeh in the labour of loce which he has now handed over to posterity
The Rev. Mr. Odeh, who had returned here from England to transfer his charge of the Mission, leaves at the end of the month for home. He has been given the living of a parish near Oxford.
Our well-wishess go out with him to his new sphere of activity

div.head: THE AMERICAN CRISIS.
div.p: A MILLIONAIRE’S POOL
RUNS ON COMPANIES.
New York, October 25

A violent slump occurred at 2 o'clock yes terday afternoon. A feverish rally followed on the announcement that a pool had been formed at the instance of Mr. Pierpont Morgan to enable brokers to close jons today. He bas already lent 24,000,000 dollars. The Southern Steel Company Birmingham (Ala bama) has failed. The Company had a capital of 25,000,000 dollars, A run has begun on the Union Trast Company of Providence (Rhode Island). (Reuter)
New York, October 25.

The Bank Examiner has announced that the accounts of the Hamilton, Twelfthward, and Empire and City Banks show that all are sol vent. The two former suspended payment owing to lack of ready cash. Altogether there is a better feeling abroad to-day. Mr. Cor telyou says that only rash and uhreasonable demands of depositors will endanger the si tuation.

(Later). The Market is still at it lowest but is steady. Receivers have been appointed far the Union Trust Company of Providence and also the Knickerbocker Trast. Two Brooklyn Banks and the! International Trust Company have suspended payment. (Reuter)

div.head: PICQUART AND HUMBERT.
div.p: STRENGTH OF FRONTIER TROOPS
Paris, October 25

Replying to a question coacerning the Hum- bert book, General Picquart refuted its asser tions, adding our frontier troops are superior tothose of Germany. The Chamber passed a vote of confidence in him. (Havas)

div.p: RELIEF FUND VOTED
Paris, October 25.
The Chamber of Deputies has voted 6,000,000 franes for the relief of the flooded districts. (Havas)

The “Times” learns from Teheran that Cabinet has been formed with Nasir-el-Malk as Premier and Minister of Finance and Mushir el-Dowleh as Foreign Minister. (Reuter)

div.head: RAILWAY CONFERENCE.
div.p: London, October 25

A conference of railway chairmen and Mr Lloyd George, lasting for an hour and a halt has been held. Conciliatory suggestions were made. The meeting was adjourned to enable the directors to copsider the matter. (Reuter)

div.p: Vancouver, October 25.
The “Empress of China” is being pumped out and the damaged cargo unloaded.(Reuter)

div.head: THE CALABRIA EARTHQUAKE
div.p: Rome, October 25

The damage in Calabria is widespread. Fer ruzzano has been completely destroyed and 200 persons killed. ‘The cathedral of Gerace has collapsed. The Government is hurrying relief to the scene of the disaster (Reuter)
Rome, October 25

Rains are aggravating the sufferings of the Calabrians who are camping in the open. Three earthquake shocks Weré telt yesterday which intensified the panic. The damage is wide spread, scarcely a village having escaped
According to the latest repgrts 300 peaple have been killed at Ferrvggano. It is estimated that altogether 500 have been killed and over 1000 injured (Reuter)
Rome, October 26

The King has given 100,000 hire and the Pope 50,000 for distribation among the sufferers lowing to the earthquake. (wing to the ener,y of the Government officials and troops a splendid start has been made in the construe tion of shelters, The battleship “Umberto 1" has gone to Reggio and Gerace. (Reuter)
Rome, October 25
The deaths from the earthquake at Ferraz zano are 500 (Havas)

div.head: EGYPTIAN FINANCES
div.p: The “Statist” writes-

“As the Egyptian Government had previously entered into large contracts for public works both in Egypt and the Sudan, it was obliged to sell 4 portion of its reserve amounting to abont a million sterling. But the fact that it did so withont due regard to the interests either of Egypt or of the International money market is quite clear from the fact that the sales excited quite alittle scare here in London, and that Sir Vincent Corbett admits that the Egyptian Exchequer lost throagh the sales a sum not exceeding L.B 70,000.

The Egyptian pound, it will be recollected is equal to 30s 6d. of our money. Conse quently, the loss on these sales in August last amounted to about £71,750. It ia to be hoped that when next the Egyptian reserves have to be drawn upon greater judgment will he used in realising the necessary funds

div.head: LOCUSTS IN THE SUDAN
div.p: Locusts are reported in large nambers from different parts of the Sudan. Dongola, Kor dotan, Kassala, Khartoum, Berber and the Blue and White Nile Provinces are alike infested with them. It is stated that they have never appeared in such large numbers in the Sudan since its restoration. But the harm done by them has not been in proportion to their numbers. Wherever they appeared, active measures, were taken by the local authorities to destroy them, or at least to drive them off So that the crops have not been damaged as seriously as would certainly have been the case if such active precautions had not been taken. Berber Province, as we learn has suf fered most from them. The last reports fron that province state that an immense flight of locuts was passing through the province measuring seven miles in length and one mile in width. The havoc wrought by such an immense army of locusts can easily be imagine

div.head: "Failure of Mohamedanism
div.p: AN interesting article from the pen of Professor Margoliouth, D. Litt, appears in the October numberof "The East and the West" under the heading of "Mohamedan Explanations of the failure of Mogamedanism. A conference at Meccah":-

"To those who are interested in the reform of the Islamic peoples - by whatever means they hope such reform may be effected- there is no more encouraging sign says the writer, than any acknowlegdement on the part of Moslems that their religion has proved inferior to some other in the mental or moral equipment of its followers. The dreary annals of Mohammedan sovereigns- many of them well-mentioned and capable men- rarely furnish evidence of any such suspicion. Sultan after Sultan builds mosques, schools of law, hospices for Sulfis, the world's ills, they suppose, are to be cured by larger and even larger quantities of the same drug, the possibility that the drug is itself inefficient or that other drugs may be more efficent is not even considered

"SO long as Islam was politically formidable this belief might remain undisrupted. The course of events which has placed by far the great majority of Moslems under Christian governments has compelled some of them to question it. A system that both in theory and in practice kept aloof from politics might not be affected by the political decadence of its adherents; but one which started as a political system, conquering and subduing, is seriously affected by circumstances which compel it to resign its imperial claims. When it can no longer be denied that for knowledge, for comfort and even for personal safety, Moslems go to countries of which the governing power is Christian, and emigrate from such as are under Moslem domination, the question why this should be suggests itself to many minds. And it is a sign of the awakening of the Moslem mind that such a question should be raised, and solutions, however inadequate, be given to it

"The title of this paper is derived from a pamphlet called Ummal Kura ("the Mother of the Villages" a name for Meccah), published at Port Said in 1316 ah (1899 ad) and purporting to contain the minutes of a debate held in Meccah on successive days from the 15th to the 29th of Dhu'l Ki'dah (March 27th to April 10) in that year. The debaters were a party of twenty three persons, assembled to discuss the reasons for the decay of Islam, and the means by which it could be resuscitated

"The chairman, having to deliver an inauguaral address, "knit his brows" but presently relaxed them, and spoke at considerable length. He regarded the question of the decadence of Islams as an old one - more than a thousand years in age, he held that there was no lack of treartises on the subject by capable writers, only that these had shrunk from going into detail; and he wound up by dividing the subject to be discussed by the society into ten heads, as follows: The seat of the disease; the accidents attending the disease; the means of applying the remedy; the essence of Islam; the way in which belief in that religion should be exhibited; the essence of secret polytheism; how innovations are to be opposed; the drawing up of rules for the foundation of a society for propaganda

"The second day a debate began with an important assertion on the part of the chairman. It was that wherever there were two neighbouring countries, districts, villages, or houses, the one Moslem and the other non Moslem, the Moslems are less energetic, worse organised in all matters, personal and social, and less skillfull in all arts and trades than the non-Moslems, though superior to the othhers in virtues, such as trustworthiness, courgae, and liberality. This sweeping assertion he was afterwards induced to restrict, when the Indian gentleman pointed out that the condition of the Moslems was superior, or not inferior, to that of Pagans and Buddhists. Someone else wished to add that of Atheists and Freethinkers but another speaker denied that such persons really existed. Evidently, then, the assertion of the chairman so far as it referred to Christian (and perhaps Parsees and Jews) was unchallenged, and now a whole series of causes began to be alleged.

When these came to be summed up at the seventh meeting, from the secretary's minutes, it was found that no fewer than fifty-six had been suggested, which could be classified as religious, political, and moral. Thus, on an average, each speaker suggested three causes some of which the secretary marks as roots, others as branches. Perhaps the whole list does not deserve translation, but there are undoubtedly some cases in which the Moslem diagnosis coincides with that given by non-Moslem physicians

The first cause suggested was thae doctrine of fatalism, which is supposed to numb effort and paralyse energy. The second was ascetic doctrine, which depreciates the value of what the world can give. From these we jump to the fifteenth, the widespread belief in an opposition between Islam and science, physical or metaphysical; and thence to the twenty-first obstinate rejection of religious liberty, through ignorance of its advantages.

On the other hand the political causes seem to be better calculated to explain the difficulty, in the few countries in which Islam is a political power. They are sixteen in number. The first is the system of government - absolute and irresponsible despotism; among the other noticable items are the prohibition of free speech, the want of equality of rights between the different classes, the want of proper encourgaement to learning the restriction of the attention of the government to the collection of taxes and the maintenance of the army. Of the presence of these evils in Islamic states with far reaching effects there is no question

The contribution made to the discussion by the Secreatry himself, who spoke after the suggestions of the others had all been registered, was much the greatest. To the fifty-six causes assigned he himself added no fewer than twenty. Of these, eleven belonged to the sphere of Ottoman administration, which the Secretary criticized somewhat in the style of Mr. Brailsford's "Macedonia" the matter contained in this section accounts for the secrecy observed, and the fact that the book could not be issued in Turkey. To the catalogue of administrative abuses which accounted for the decadence of Islam he added a list of nine miscellaneous causes, of which the first seems still to belong exculsively to the Ottoman Empire, but remainder hold good of Mohammedan countries generally. Cause 83, "Neglect of female education" constitues so real an explanation of some of the phenomena that it may be worth while translating the paragraph devoted to it in the Secretary's speech; "The weakness of our characters is to be accounted for by yet another important cuase, connected with women - I mean their being left ignorantm unlike what the case with our sncestors, when women were to be found like A'ishah, Mother of the Believers, with whom God be pleased, from whom we have recieved half our theological knowlegde. So, too, there were hundreds of women in the time of the Companions of the Prophet and the Epigoni, who recited tradtions, and were authorities on points of law, not to mention thousands who possessed knowlegde and composed verses. The existence of these women at the commencement of Islam is a convincing arguement, sufficient to refute those who hold that ignorance is the best safegaurd for a women's chastity - not to mention the fact that no proof can be adduced for the supposition that knowledge leads to looseness of morals, and ignorance to strictness. For if knowlegde render a woman more capable of sinning, ignorance will giver her greater boldness. The mischief produced by female ignorance and its evil effects on the character of the children, both male and female, are mattersthat are obvious and require no exposition. Only its evil effect on the charcter of the husband is not quite so conspicuous, and may need some elneidation

Men have a anrtual affection for their wives a tendency to be influenced by their moral qualities; the contrary of this is only imagined by such a man as has been cajoled by his wifre into the belief that she is a poor weak thing, completely subject to his will, whereas the fact, she holds the reins, and can guide him whither she chooses; or to put it otherwise, into the belief that he is the leader and she the follower, whereas the truth percieved by all around, though unperceived by the husband himslef, is that she follows him in the capacity of driver, not of driven. The astuteness of women has been most adequately gauged by the Islamic codes, which prescribed the veil and the seculsion of the harem in order to restrict their power, and to confine it to the management of the hosue the veil, to the ectent of not displaying their ornaments to strange men, and not meeting them in private or unnecessarily; and confinement to the house, except for pressing needs - there being no doubt that what is outside these limits opens the door to licentiousness. And these restrictions are enjoined out of consideration for the husbands, and with a view to the proper allocation of the duties of life. The Chinese, whose civilization is the oldest, instututed the forcible compression of girls' feet as to render it difficult for them to move about, and endanger their hounor - which with the Orientals is the primary consideration, whereas Westerns are only concerned with material comforts"

The discussions of teh debaters, however interesting, appear to have rendered of little practical value by their failures to define accurately the essence of progress, and to study the history of Islam by the light so obtained. Has Islam any Golden Age to look back on, except in the sense that at one time Mohamedan Sultans were a terror to their neighbours, whereas now their neighbours are safe from their raids! There is no real abuse current in Mohamedan States from which they have been free, except by accident for a limited time, on the other hand, reforms, whether forced upon the people from outside or not, have been introduced - it is sufficient to point to the abolition of slavery, at least over the greater area of Islam. The days of the Pious Caliphs, could they have been reproduced, would mean no progress even in the most backward of Islamic countries. The strengthening of Islam, if it is not to be a calamity to the whole world, is not to be effected by the reproduction of a barbarous past, but by an attempt to utilise the vast force which Islam represents, as a factor in real progress, the civilising and ennobling of the race. And whether this can be done or the whole of this huge capital must be "written of" is the question which reformers have to solve"

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 25 Octobre.
La Semaine

Notre marché a présenté lundi le méme aspect déprimé que la semaine derniére. C’était daillears 4 prévoir avec la faiblesse du Stock Exchange. b'activitéa fait complétement défant et les transactions effectades ont été limitées anx United, Agricole, Union Fonciére et Casas di Seonto.

Le lendemain, toute |'animation s'est eon centrée sur le Comptoir quia de la sorte béné- ticié de 18 Il y a ea également quelques affaires clairsemées en National Bank, Agri ole, Delta Land, Nungovich Hotels, Salt & Soda et Cassa di Sconto.

Mercredi le Comptoir a encore absorbé tonte lattention des petits spéculateurs. C'était le Caite qui vendait, témoin l'setivité déployée par les arbitragistes On a anssi traité, mais en quantité et nombre insignifiants, la National Bank, la Delta Land, Agricole et les Rite Hotels

Avec les mauvaises noovelles transmises.hier de Londres ot la dépression des valears amé ricaines paralyse le Stock Bxebange, nous avons en ici le contre-coup de la paniqne générale. On a ouvert en pleine réaction sur les titres en vogne, pour se raffermir tant soit peu vers la fin de la séance, mais en cliturant tout de méme & un niveau inférieur 4 celai de la veille. Des transactions, un peu plas nombreunes et importantes, quoique toujours limitées, ont pu étre effectudes a la faveur d'une réduction dans les prix.en Delta Land, Comptoir, Gassa di Seonto et Khediviel Mail

Comme on s‘attendait ce matin 4 aneélévation du taux d'escompte de la Banque d’ Angleterre, le fait que cette banque n'a pas cra névessaire d’y procéder de suite a produit une bonne im pression. Cepeodant, la faiblesse du Stock Exchange et la panique américaine outexercé ici une certaine influence, peu visible dans la cote dont les fluctuations .n’ont pas eu d’en vergure, mais fort sensible dans le mouvement des transactions. Alors que les vendeurs (haus siers) trouvaient péniblement jusqu'ici des acquéreurs moyennant des réductions daus lenrs exigences, aujourd'hui jl leur était presque impossible de décoavrir an client. Les ama teurs se tont de plus en plas rares. Et s'il nous faut dire que l’animation a porté prineipale- ment sur le Comptoir, la Cassa di Seonto et la Delta Land, on eomprendra qu'il s'agit surtout de tapage et d’offres de vente. Le seul titre qui ait atédemandé au prix d’bier est I'l- nion Foneiere: Quant anx valenrs dirigeantes elles sont tonjours négligées
Les Frurctuarions pe La Core

Dans de telles conditions on ne sera pas surpris de constater que sur une soixantaine de valeurs inserites a la cote officielle de la Bourse d’Alexandrie plas de trente snient en taisse et dix seulement en hausse

Dans ce nombre, les flactoations les plus remarquables sont les suivantes: la National Bank et | Alexandria Water perdent une 1/% livre aux cours respectifs de 21 3/8 et 11, la Béhéra 7.8 a 23, la Delta Land 1/441 1/4, les Sucreries 9 frances 4 31, le Cheikh Fadl 5 trancs 4 90 et les Jonissances Eaux du Caire 4 franes 4 190. Seulsles Nungovich Hotels re gagnent une 12 livre 4171/4. Pour la plo part de ces titres ce sont des offres owdes demandes sans contre partie qui ont fait mo difier les prix

Sur le reste de la cote les changements ont peu d'importance. L' Agricole perd 5/32, la Rem leh, la Delta Light, la Daira, la Privilégiée Khé divial Mail, la Land Bank, les Splendid Ho tels, l'shaine, l'setion Allotment, ts fondatenr United et la Zariffa 1/8 chacane, les Tramways d’Alexandrie Privilégiées, les actions de capita! Eaux da Caire et le Banco di Roma 1 franc, les Markets 9 pence, |'Obligation nouvelle Crédit Poncier 50 eentimes, la Banque d’Athénes | fr. 50, Aboukir et la Port Said Salt 6 pence, |'In vestment et la Building Lands +/32, les Esta tes, les Ritz Hotels et la Levico 1/16, la Ban aed Orient 3 tranes, et lafondateur Allotment 2 P.T. L'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foneier les Lots Turcs et la Cassa di Sconto gagnent, au contraire, 1 franc, l'Ordinary Kheivial Mail 6 pence, le Comptoir 3/32, Union Pon citre et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien 1 16, et l'United 1/32
Nos Praers Dirigeantes

Sur nos places dirigeantes, les waleurs egyp tiennes, exceptionnetlement recherehees il y a quelques semaines, ont peu a peo subi le sort des autres. Elles sont anjoord’bai totalement négligées & dea cours légérement plus taibles ue vendredi dernier. Au Stock Exchange, la Daira et la National Bank reculent 4 13 1/2et 21 5/8, en perte de 1/4, |'Agricale et la Delta Light 48 1/4 et 40:@/8, en pertede 1s. Le Consolidé Anglais-est admirablement souteau © 83 1/4, ce qui représente uneavance de 3/8 sur la semaine pansée. A Paris, l'action de Suez rétrograde de 4625 a 4595, le Crédit Poncier Egyptien de 698 4 693, Ja Land Bank of Egypt de 185 & 182, Ia Banque d’Athénes de 111 4 110 et le Crédit Franco-Bgyptien de 109 & 106.50. Comme le Consolidé, la Rente Francaise, suivant un mouvement coutraire A lensemble du marché, progresse de 94.10 a 94.27
La Situation Generale

Il y avait lopgtemps que -nons n'avions eo une sitaation générale sassi sombre. Comme la derniége. fois, le nuage meus vient d’ Amériqve, ob rogne la panique & Walt-Street. Des faillites sensationoelies se produisent. Plusieurs grands ¢tablissements ‘financiers sont [objet d'un “tun” irrésistible. Le seorétaire da Trésor Améeienin, pour prévenir une aggravation de la nervosité générale et la transformation ‘le la crise-en débacle, s'est reodo mercredi a New- York pour técher de ramener on peu de cqnfidmce sur le marché, aseorant que le

Trésor viendtait 7 side A tous les établis- sements qui le méritent. Et teaduisant im médiatement ses paroles en actes, apres en avoir conféré avec les principaux fi nanciers de ja localité, il a déposé hier 10 millions de dollars dena les banques loceles. De leur cété, les milliardaires américains ont Promis leur concours et ont consenti déja des préts considérables. Ces déclarations ras surantes ont un peu calmé les esprite surex cités, maix, qooique le seorétaire du Trésor ait affirmé qu'il envinageait les plos graves difficoltes comme passées, il n'en reste pas moins que l'avenir dépend beaucoap de Iha bileté avec laquelle on manwuvrera en haut lev. Le toumant est diffeile. Pourtant, la finance amétionine estime qu'il n'y aurk pas besoin d'importer beaucoup de noméraire ; de || Plas elle se rend parfaitement compte de Jim portance quil ya ponr tout le monde a ne pas déterminer ane nouvelle rédection de la réserve de la Banque d' Angleterre

On congoit que de tels événements ne soient pas de natore & consolider un marché déja éprouvé par ape ‘crise, dont il ne s'est pas encore relevé. Aussi a Londres comme sur le-eontinent les bourses ont témoigné de la manvaise tameur et one baisse correspon. datite a suivi. Heurensement, les capitalistes européens ne sont pas chargés outre mesure de valeurs amériesines. cest ce qui expliqne l'effet relativament pew sensible que la nouvelle a produit an Stock Exchange. La Bangne d’An gleterre qu'on craignait de voir angmenter im. médiatement sov tanx d'escompte pour pro Léger sa reserve u'& pris jusqu ter auoane mesure dans ce sens, et malgré les appels qui ont été faite & ses cainses, le peopertion de sa réserve so maintient avantageusement en comparaison de Yannée dernitre; elle est sealement de 21/8 %, inférieure a celle de vendredi dervier.

Un évinement financier qui pent avoir un retentissement mondial par le drainage de nu- méraire qu'il produira en an moment de cherté exceptionnelle de |'argent, c'est le prochain emprant rasse dont on parle an pen partout. C'est «la négociation de cet emprunt qu'on rattache la visite a Paris de Kokovtzof. On nous tranquillise pour |'instant en nous as surant que la Prance ne consentirait ce nou veau prét que moyennant des garanties légales, par lesquelles on entend la sanction d'un parie- ment. D'ici 1A nous aurons peut-tre le temps de nons remettre des émotions présentes.
En Egypte

Ici, Vinfluence de la crise américaine ne s'est pas fait sentir- dans ia mesure of on aurait pu le redeuter, si la spéenlation s'était lancée dans les mancuvres de l'anne derni¢re Ce n'est pourtant pas l'envie qui loi en a mangu4é Mais elle s'est trouvée paralysée par la réserve prodente du capital et de l'épar ane, la disette monétaire et l'inexistence du marché 4 terme. C'est le cas de dire qua quel que chose malhenur est bon

Sans nous arréter a l'opinion de quelques uns, suivant lesquels l'animation intermittente qui régne sur un petit groupe de valears spé culatives est la réédition de pratiques maintes fois répét‘es pour tromper l'épargne, on sera bien obligé de reconnaitre qa'en nous tenant dans la note modérée nous avons vn plas juste que les pottes lyriques de la hausse, inlassables proph tes d'une reprise définitive jonrnelle ment démentie par les faits
Quelques Informations Financieres

Depuis queljne temps l'United est l'objet de vives eritiqnes. Son conseil d'adméinistration, qui eat particuli¢rement pris 4 partie, a tenn mercredi one réqnion chez M.M. Carver Bros & Co. ot les créanciers de la société avaient également été convoqués. [| s'agissait de né gocier une entente pour le paiement des ter. rains de Rodah (57 feddans). div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton

Bien des personnes ont certainement df trouver que, dans un moment d effervescence comme celui que nous traversions ce joar-la, la note de notre dernitre revue était trop peswimiste et que de la facon dont les choses se passaient, on pouvait 4 la rigueur considérer la situation comme n’étant pas si noire que nons le disions. Avec les dispositions appazen- tes du marché, une telle impression était excusable ; mais maintenant que les evénements ont mmencé a abonder dans notre sens et beaucoup plus tot que cous ne le pensions nousmémes, nos contradicteurs soutiendront ils encore que nous sommes baissiers par nature !

Certes, l'impréva a aidé a précipiter le revirement, mais cet ipréva n'était apres tout pas si inattendu, car plus d'une fois nous avions mentionné la crise financiére en Améri- que comme tne des raisons de baisse dent il fallait tenir compte.

En somme, le mouvement baussier qué nous avons 6u était intempestif et malencontreux, mais il est encore heurenx que les choses, volontairement on foreément, se soient atrétées & temps, autrement, les conséqnences, avec nos difficultés financiéres qui n'ont pas endore disparu, auraient pu devenir plas gramee pour ceux qui avaient commence a s'emballer com ple ternent et qui croyaient qu'il n'y avait plus qu'a aller de l'avant

Quant A leftenme do marché pendentia se- maine, elle « 4é6-den plas-wariables, tantét feu ot famme stivent le manque de ven@eet ov lexcitation dewaehetarr'et tantot faible ot en bainse, sufviit ler nouvelles de debor oe les ombargaements. Le fait est que les inté ressés ont marché 4 tétona, cherchant ment 4 profiter des occasions pour r jeu

Samedi aprés un cébet calme et ow baine, ane tentative de soutien #' Cte Mite" par le parti de la haduse et commé d'une ino pinée la corbeille laissa volf des dispositions & avancer, l'sadace sen méla et le coum.da No- vembre fut poussé jusqu'a 20 1/8

Lundi, 4 louverture, et malgré les efforts des hanssiers, bn faiblense » prs ls plate dob fermeté et la cloture deheure a eu lien a 19 3 4. Dans Heprie-tidiy toutefois, la ten dance « thangé eur apparition de quelques achetears"tidsireut* de profiter des cours ré ghants et comime cmsdquence, le prix a $té immédiatement porté 4 P9 15/16
Mardi, apres les cours successifede 19 7/8 et 201/16, lemaroné « fidchi guatutiiement poor finir le soir & 19 28 32 et cela sous le poids des ventes du Commerce.
Mais la mavvaise journée a ¢té réellement celle da lendemain, pendant dagquelle jes haus siers ont montré da désourngement, ce qui a permis 4 leurs adversaires d'éerkser be No vembre 4 19 9/82.

Hier, en guise de revanche et qooique ln cloture de New-York fit horrible, le clan have sier s'est livré A une manipolation dé le pre mitre minute et o réussi 4 soutenir dee esters. En résamé ac total il y a eo pourite deux seances réunies ane reprise le 1/4 46 tallari

Anjoord’bui, l'allare a été changeante, soit calme au commencement, ferme et en hagese ensuite; en réaction au nivean d’bier dete fin de ia séance de matin, metilearedans frtbirée, nous clétoron= In “setinine sat la cots af 19 19/32, ce qui nows fait en définitive 9/16 de baisse snr vendredi dernier, les cours maximum et minimum pratiqués dans l'intervalle étant de 20 5/32 et 19 9/32 respectivement.

Dans les conditions que nous. verons d’ex poser, la semaine a été aprés tout tebe. imtéres- sante, mais on frémit 4 penser aux eonséquen ces dn toupet'des haussiers 4 persister'dans la voie ob ils se sot engagés. Ce n'est plas gues tion de manceuvres en vue d'un décoogert & exploiter, c'est de l'emballement, dela frénésie, le |'aliénation mentale-efme, si ce n'est le latte du désespoir tout ce que nous véyont se dérooler la devant nous , car {l n'y a pal Tin telligetice humaine qui puisse admetire que de sang froid on puisse pousser les coors 4 un niseau comme tectect sort an demble de la valeur de l’ Américain

Mais une récoite de 5 1/8 millions de can tars jostifierait a peine un écart pareil a payer par la filatare et c'est plas de 7 millions que nous avons en perspective Il est vrei que par moment, dans les grandes années de spécula tion, nous avons eu de ces mouvements dérai sonnables, mais ce sont des choses qui’ ont tonjonrs été pansagéres et qubse wont prodnites de Mars A Mai, et aprés que le 80 ou le 90 , le notre production talent vendus & la con sommation, tandis qu'anjourd’hui nous som ines encore en Octobre et avec le 40 %, a peine de la recolte d'engage. Il est certain qu'on ne saurait mieux faire pour réduire l'emploi de l'Egyptien au minipem, ou pour compltter notre propre ruine Qu’on nous taxe d'oiseau le mauvais augure et de tout ce qu'on voudra, ela ne nous enpéchera pas de crief A ceux qui ont l'air d’avoir perda tohte notion de la réalité “prenez garde, vous étes en train de préparer une catastrophe et 4 bref délai méme et notre place n'a nallement besoin d'an now vean malheur

A la rigueur on aarait pa admettre quelqves folies sur notre marché si |’ Amérique nous avait fourni quelque prétente, mais de ce obté la que voyons-nous | ‘Basse précipitde a la suite de la formidable crise financiére qui sévit Whas et qui nous vaut chaque jour Vannonce de deux on trois nouvelles sus pensions ov faillites, représentant des mil lions et des millions de dollars, sans un espoir damélioration mamédiate dans la situation, et vela malgré le secours du Trésor qui fait des avances aux Banques pour les affaires légitimes et l'aide des:nekes pour tacher de sauver ce qui pourrait encore tenir deboat. On pareit-ne par-se-rencdre rompt® sar notre place de |'importance de ces é¢vénements financiers ete teers vombédhéhder et nous avons méme entendu dire par quelqu'en qu'en fin de compte notre crise 4 nous n's pas boule versé I'Cnivers ' En face d’énormitée de on genre, il n'y aurait qu’ tirer I'tchellepa@ais nous youlons oroire qu'il ne s agissiit qaw dew sinsple ‘bedinage ; ‘en tous cas, i] nous tefttiy qu'au tien de wamtmer 4 suppater les conag, quences de faits auési gravesque coug que meas avons devant nous, on-ferait beancoap aieux
